title: Cold-pressed juice is now being marketed to the craft cocktail set
text:
The bottle: Twisted Alchemy cold-pressed juice, $15.50.

The back story: Americans have increasingly turned to cold-pressed juice as a fresh-tasting, health-minded alternative, with the idea being that juice prepared in this way better preserves the vitamins and minerals. Sales in the category are expected to nearly double by 2024 to $8.1 billion, according to a report from Wintergreen Research.

So, what’s next? A line of cold-pressed juices geared for the craft cocktail crowd, of course.

That’s the thought behind Twisted Alchemy, a brand that started in 2016 (originally, it was called Industry Juice). It’s the brainchild of Kim and Scott Holstein, food-and-drink-loving entrepreneurs who previously developed Kim and Scott’s Gourmet Pretzels, a brand the couple sold everywhere from Whole Foods AMZ, +0.64% to QVC. The story goes that one night the couple was preparing a big batch of margaritas with fresh lime juice and they got tired of squeezing the fruit. “We needed a solution to create the fresh-squeezed taste but without all the hours of work,” says Kim Holstein. Twisted Alchemy was born.

The brand has grown to encompass several varieties — not just lime, but also key lime, lemon, grapefruit, watermelon, pineapple orange and even blood orange. Sales were up a remarkable 538% in 2018, Kim Holstein notes.

The couple is largely targeting Twisted Alchemy at bars and restaurants and says the products are also popular with spirits brands at special events and cocktail-making classes. But consumers can partake as well — the juices can be ordered online for direct shipping.

What we think about it: There’s no question this is quality juice — the flavors truly pop (we’re very partial to the lime and orange). We also like that the juice has a long-shelf life (at least 90 days), thanks to a process the brand uses that preserves the liquid without utilizing pasteurization, which can kill the taste. The only negative? The juice is very pricey, as is typically the case with cold-pressed products. A six-pack of various flavors sells for $93 directly from the company.

How to enjoy it: In cocktails, naturally! But if money is not an issue, the juice can certainly be had on its own. It also works well in alcohol-free cocktails (aka mocktails). And Kim Holstein says the lemon juice can be had in the morning as a wake-up for the digestive system.
description: Twisted Alchemy brand has seen remarkable sales growth.
